1.title: The Fundamentals of Geometry
1.subtitle: Definitions, Postulates, and Common Notions
1.introduction: Book 1 lays the foundational concepts and propositions for geometry. It begins by establishing key definitions, postulates, and common notions which serve as the basic assumptions and rules for reasoning in geometry. The propositions then build up from these foundations.

propositionGroups.name: Basic Constructions
propositionGroups.description: Constructing equilateral triangles, copying line segments, cutting line segments.

propositionGroups.name: Congruent Triangles
propositionGroups.description: Establishing when two triangles are congruent based on side and angle equality.

propositionGroups.name: Angle Relations
propositionGroups.description: Relationships between angles formed by intersecting lines.

propositionGroups.name: Triangle Inequalities
propositionGroups.description: Inequalities between angles and sides in a triangle.

propositionGroups.name: Parallels and Parallelograms
propositionGroups.description: Properties of parallel lines and parallelograms.

propositionGroups.name: Triangles and Parallelograms
propositionGroups.description: Relationships between triangles and parallelograms.

propositionGroups.name: Constructions using Parallelograms
propositionGroups.description: Constructing parallelograms equal in area to triangles and other figures.

propositionGroups.name: The Square and its Properties
propositionGroups.description: Constructing squares and relating square sides to triangle sides.

2.title: Geometric Algebra
2.subtitle: Applications of Areas
2.introduction: Book 2 develops geometric algebra by establishing relations between rectangles and squares on straight line segments. These are then used to solve geometric problems like constructing squares equal in area to a given rectangle.

propositionGroups.name: Rectangles and Squares
propositionGroups.description: Relations between rectangles and squares constructed on straight line segments.

propositionGroups.name: Cutting Line Segments
propositionGroups.description: Cutting line segments so that rectangles and squares constructed on them have certain relations.

propositionGroups.name: Triangles and Squares
propositionGroups.description: Comparing squares constructed on sides of triangles to squares on other related straight lines.

propositionGroups.name: Constructions
propositionGroups.description: Constructing squares equal in area to given figures using the propositions proved.

3.title: The Circle
3.subtitle: Properties of Circles
3.introduction: Book 3 develops various theorems about circles using results from the earlier books. It covers topics like tangents, chords, angles inscribed in circles, and constructs segments of circles.

propositionGroups.name: Tangents and Chords
propositionGroups.description: Basic properties of tangents and chords related to circles.

propositionGroups.name: Angles in Circles
propositionGroups.description: Angles formed by chords, diameters, radii and tangents.

propositionGroups.name: Segments of Circles
propositionGroups.description: Constructing segments of circles related to given angles.

propositionGroups.name: Contact and Intersection
propositionGroups.description: Circles meeting at points of contact.

propositionGroups.name: Central Angles and Arcs
propositionGroups.description: Central angles are twice angles at circumference on same arc.

propositionGroups.name: Inscribed Figures
propositionGroups.description: Properties of figures inscribed in circles.

4.title: Book 4 - Circles
4.subtitle: Constructions and Theorems on Circles
4.introduction: Book 4 covers constructions and theorems involving circles. It begins by establishing basic constructions for circles such as fitting a line segment into a circle. The propositions then cover topics like inscribing and circumscribing triangles, squares, and regular polygons in circles.

propositionGroups.name: Constructing Line Segments in Circles
propositionGroups.description: Fitting given line segments into circles and constructing line segments equal to given segments using circles.

propositionGroups.name: Inscribed and Circumscribed Triangles
propositionGroups.description: Inscribing triangles in circles and circumscribing triangles about circles based on angle properties.

propositionGroups.name: Inscribed and Circumscribed Squares
propositionGroups.description: Inscribing and circumscribing squares in and about circles.

propositionGroups.name: Inscribed and Circumscribed Isosceles Triangles
propositionGroups.description: Constructing isosceles triangles with prescribed angle properties to inscribe and circumscribe in circles.

propositionGroups.name: Regular Inscribed and Circumscribed Polygons
propositionGroups.description: Inscribing and circumscribing equilateral, equiangular pentagons, hexagons, and 15-sided figures in circles.

5.title: Book 5 - Ratios and Proportions
5.subtitle: Theories of Ratios and Proportional Magnitudes
5.introduction: Book 5 covers the theory of ratios and proportions between magnitudes of the same kind. It begins by defining key concepts like ratio, proportion, equimultiples, and perturbed proportion. The propositions then develop general theorems about ratios and proportions, including alternation, inversion, composition, and separation of ratios.

propositionGroups.name: Preliminary Definitions
propositionGroups.description: Defining concepts like ratio, proportion, equimultiples, greater ratio, and perturbed proportion.

propositionGroups.name: Fundamentals of Ratios
propositionGroups.description: Basic theorems relating ratios to equality, inequality, and composition of ratios.

propositionGroups.name: Ratios and Proportional Magnitudes
propositionGroups.description: Properties and theorems relating ratios to proportional magnitudes including alteration, inversion, separation, and composition.

propositionGroups.name: Properties of Proportions
propositionGroups.description: Additional theorems on proportions like summing ratios and ratios of greatest/least magnitudes.

6.title: Book 6 - Similar Figures
6.subtitle: Theory of Proportion and Similarity
6.introduction: Book 6 develops the theory of proportion and similarity between figures. It begins with key definitions like similar figures and extreme/mean ratio. The propositions then cover topics like proportional sides in similar triangles, dividing lines in extreme/mean ratio, similar polygons, applying parallelograms to straight lines, and similarities between circles.

propositionGroups.name: Basic Principles
propositionGroups.description: Fundamental propositions relating proportional sides of triangles and ratios of segments.

propositionGroups.name: Similar Triangles
propositionGroups.description: Criteria for similarity of triangles based on angles and proportional sides.

propositionGroups.name: Extreme and Mean Ratio
propositionGroups.description: Dividing straight lines in extreme and mean ratio and properties of such divisions.

propositionGroups.name: Similar Figures
propositionGroups.description: Similarity and proportionality between polygons and parallelograms.

propositionGroups.name: Applications of Similar Figures
propositionGroups.description: Applying parallelograms to straight lines and related constructions.

propositionGroups.name: Circles
propositionGroups.description: Similarity of angles and arcs in circles.

7.title: Elementary Number Theory
7.subtitle: Propositions on Numbers
7.introduction: Book 7 covers fundamental concepts and properties related to numbers and operations on numbers, providing a foundation for number theory.

propositionGroups.name: Basic Definitions
propositionGroups.description: Key definitions relating to units, numbers, divisibility, prime numbers, multiples, factors, and proportionality.

propositionGroups.name: Properties of Numbers
propositionGroups.description: Propositions establishing properties of prime, composite, and relatively prime numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Greatest Common Measure
propositionGroups.description: Finding the greatest common measure of two or more numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Least Common Multiple
propositionGroups.description: Finding the least common multiple of two or more numbers.

8.title: Proportions in Numbers
8.introduction: Book 8 covers proportions and means between numbers, including properties of numbers in continued proportion and similar plane and solid numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Proportions and Means
propositionGroups.description: Properties of numbers in continued proportion and finding mean proportionals.

propositionGroups.name: Plane and Solid Numbers
propositionGroups.description: Properties and ratios between plane numbers, solid numbers, squares and cubes.

propositionGroups.name: Prime Numbers
propositionGroups.description: Properties of prime numbers in proportion.

9.title: Number Theory
9.introduction: Book 9 covers fundamental number theory concepts like properties of even and odd numbers, squares, cubes, ratios between numbers, and perfect numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Properties of Odd/Even Numbers
propositionGroups.description: Basic properties and operations with odd and even numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Squares and Cubes
propositionGroups.description: Properties of squares and cubes derived by multiplying numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Prime Numbers
propositionGroups.description: Properties of prime numbers.

propositionGroups.name: Ratios
propositionGroups.description: Ratios between numbers in proportion.

propositionGroups.name: Perfect Numbers
propositionGroups.description: Perfect numbers equal to the sum of their proper divisors.

10.title: Book 10 - Classification of Incommensurables
10.introduction: Book 10 classifies different types of incommensurable magnitudes and their properties. It builds on the theory of proportion developed in earlier books.

propositionGroups.name: Definitions of Incommensurables
propositionGroups.description: Definitions relating to commensurable and incommensurable magnitudes.

propositionGroups.name: Theorems on Commensurables and Incommensurables
propositionGroups.description: Properties and relationships between commensurable and incommensurable magnitudes.

propositionGroups.name: Applications
propositionGroups.description: Constructing examples of incommensurables with various properties.

propositionGroups.name: Classification of Irrationals
propositionGroups.description: Definitions and constructions of irrationals like binomials, bimedials, apotomes, and medials.

propositionGroups.name: Properties of Binomials and Apotomes
propositionGroups.description: Proving properties and relationships between different types of irrationals.

propositionGroups.name: Areas Related to Irrationals
propositionGroups.description: Finding the side of squares equal in area to rectangles formed by irrationals.

propositionGroups.name: Properties of Incommensurables
propositionGroups.description: Relationships between incommensurable magnitudes.

propositionGroups.name: Constructions of Apotomes
propositionGroups.description: Constructions of different types of apotomes.

propositionGroups.name: Areas Related to Apotomes
propositionGroups.description: Finding squares equal in area to rectangles formed by apotomes.

propositionGroups.name: Comparisons
propositionGroups.description: Comparing properties of apotomes and binomials.

propositionGroups.name: Miscellaneous Proofs
propositionGroups.description: Additional propositions about properties of incommensurables.

propositionGroups.name: Infinity of Irrationals
propositionGroups.description: There are infinitely many irrationals.

11.title: Three-Dimensional Geometry
11.subtitle: Definitions, Axioms, and Propositions on Solid Geometry
11.introduction: Book 11 introduces the foundations of three-dimensional geometry. It begins with definitions of fundamental concepts like solid, plane, angle, and parallel planes. The propositions then build up theories about solid angles, properties of parallelepipedal solids, and relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional figures.

propositionGroups.name: Fundamentals
propositionGroups.description: Basic axioms relating points, lines, and planes in three dimensions.

propositionGroups.name: Perpendiculars and Parallels
propositionGroups.description: Establishing perpendicularity and parallelism for lines and planes.

propositionGroups.name: Solid Angles
propositionGroups.description: Defining solid angles and establishing their properties.

propositionGroups.name: Parallelepipeds
propositionGroups.description: Defining parallelepipeds and relating their dimensions, sides, areas, and volumes.

propositionGroups.name: Miscellaneous Constructions
propositionGroups.description: Constructions relating points, lines, planes, and solids.

12.title: Measurement of Figures
12.subtitle: Area, Volume, and Dimension Ratios
12.introduction: Book 12 develops formulas and techniques for determining areas, volumes, and dimension ratios of plane and solid figures. It builds on the foundation of similar figures from Book 6.

propositionGroups.name: Areas of Circles and Polygons
propositionGroups.description: Relating areas of circles, inscribed polygons, and diameters.

propositionGroups.name: Volumes of Pyramids and Cones
propositionGroups.description: Dividing pyramids into pieces and relating volumes of pyramids, cones, and prisms.

propositionGroups.name: Volumes of Cylinders and Spheres
propositionGroups.description: Relating volumes of cylinders, spheres, bases, heights, and diameters.

13.title: The Regular Solids
13.subtitle: Construction of the Platonic Solids
13.introduction: Book 13 constructs the 5 regular or Platonic solids - tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron. It develops formulas relating their edges, faces, and dimensions.

propositionGroups.name: Extreme and Mean Ratio
propositionGroups.description: Properties and constructions using extreme and mean ratio.

propositionGroups.name: Regular Polygons
propositionGroups.description: Equiangular and equilateral properties of pentagons, hexagons, and decagons.

propositionGroups.name: The Platonic Solids
propositionGroups.description: Constructing and inscribing the tetrahedron, cube, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron.
